gt:
Sure thing! Let's dive into the sewing tasks that use Silk. Here's a neat table summarizing the details for you:

| Sewing Task ID | Start Time       | End Time         | Working Group Name | Order Product ID | Planned Number | Completed Number | Status       |
|----------------|------------------|------------------|--------------------|------------------|----------------|------------------|--------------|
| 11             | 2024-03-21       | 2024-04-14       | Premier Sewers     | 11               | 140            | 100              | In Progress  |
| 12             | 2024-03-27       | 2024-04-12       | Master Sewers      | 12               | 150            | 120              | Completed    |
| 13             | 2024-03-27       | 2024-04-06       | Master Sewers      | 13               | 130            | 120              | Completed    |
| 14             | 2024-03-18       | 2024-04-08       | Master Sewers      | 14               | 120            | 120              | Completed    |

These tasks are handled by the talented Premier Sewers and Master Sewers teams. Keep up the great work! üòÑ

steps.sql: SELECT id FROM materials WHERE name = 'Silk';
steps.description: Retrieve the material ID for the material with the name "Silk"

steps.sql: SELECT id FROM warehouse_material WHERE material_id = '5';
steps.description: Retrieve the warehouse material IDs that correspond to the material ID for "Silk"

steps.sql: SELECT sewing_task_id FROM sewing_material_allocation WHERE warehouse_material_id IN ('5');
steps.description: Retrieve the sewing task IDs that use the warehouse material IDs for "Silk"

steps.sql: SELECT st.id, st.start_time, st.end_time, wg.name AS working_group_name, op.id AS order_product_id, st.planned_number, st.completed_number, st.status FROM sewing_tasks st JOIN working_group wg ON st.working_group_id = wg.id JOIN order_product op ON st.order_product_id = op.id WHERE st.id IN ('11', '12', '13', '14');
steps.description: Retrieve the details of the sewing tasks that use "Silk"
